# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt #visualize
plt.style.use("seaborn-whitegrid")

# plotly
# import plotly.plotly as py
from plotly.offline import init_notebook_mode, iplot, plot
import plotly as py
init_notebook_mode(connected=True)

import plotly.graph_objs as go

# word cloud library
from wordcloud import WordCloud

import seaborn as sns #visualize

from collections import Counter

import warnings # don't show warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

source.a30b5145:
# We write a function to quickly browse through the numerical feature
# We can have a small information about our numerical features by examining the histograms.
def plot_hist(variable):
    """
    input : variable ex : "Ladder score"
    output : Hist plot  
    """
    plt.figure(figsize=(9,3))
    plt.hist(world_happiness_report_2021[variable])
    plt.xlabel(variable)
    plt.ylabel("Frequency")
    plt.title("{} distribution with hist ".format(variable))
    plt.show()

for n in numericVar:
    plot_hist(n)

source.f44508be:
# we write our function to find the outlier
def detect_outliers(df,features):
    outlier_indices = []
    
    for c in features:
        # 1st quartile
        Q1 = np.percentile(df[c],25)
        # 3st quartile
        Q3 = np.percentile(df[c],75)
        # IQR
        IQR = Q3 - Q1
        # Outlier Step
        outlier_step = IQR * 1.5
        # detect outlier and their indeces
        outlier_list_col = df[(df[c] < Q1 - outlier_step) | (df[c] > Q3 + outlier_step)].index
        # store indeces 
        outlier_indices.extend(outlier_list_col)
        
    outlier_indices = Counter(outlier_indices)
    """
    ## Usually at least 2 outliers in a row we drop.
    ## if there are two discrete values
    """
    multiple_outliers = list(i for i, v in outlier_indices.items() if v > 2) 
    
    return multiple_outliers

source.b470aa3e:
### Social support and Freedom to make life choices vs Ladder score of Top 30 Countries

# top 30 countries in the world ranking
top_countries_onehundred = world_happiness_report_2021.iloc[:30,:]
"""
rgba(red,green,blue,alpha) = different color rendering.
You can create the color you want by changing the values.

"""
# Creating trace1(Social Support)
trace1 = go.Scatter(
                    x = top_countries_onehundred["Ladder score"], # x-axis
                    y = top_countries_onehundred["Social support"], # y-axis
                    mode = "lines", # how to draw
                    name = "Social support",
                    marker = dict(color = 'rgba(255, 20, 30, 1)'),# color of the lines
                    text= top_countries_onehundred["Country name"]) # text on hover
# Creating trace2(Freedom to make life choices)
trace2 = go.Scatter(
                    x = top_countries_onehundred["Ladder score"],# x-axis
                    y = top_countries_onehundred["Freedom to make life choices"], # y-axis
                    mode = "lines+markers", # how to draw
                    name = "Freedom to make life choices",
                    marker = dict(color = 'rgba(15, 99, 36, 0.8)'),
                    text= top_countries_onehundred["Country name"])

# we combine our two traces
data = [trace1, trace2]
# outer part of the chart
layout = dict(title = 'Social support and Freedom to make life choices vs Ladder score of Top 30 Countries',
              xaxis= dict(title= 'Ladder score',ticklen= 15,zeroline= False)
             )
# We combine our data and layout
# create figure
fig = dict(data = data, layout = layout)
iplot(fig) # draw the chart

### Comparison of the 3 values of the top five countries.
### (Social support,Freedom to make life choices,Perceptions of corruption)

# top 5 countries in happiness ranking
df2021 = world_happiness_report_2021.iloc[:5,:]

# create trace1(Social Support)
trace1 = go.Bar(
                x = df2021["Country name"], # x-axis
                y = df2021["Social support"], # y-axis
                name = "Social support", # text to the right of the chart
                marker = dict(color = 'rgba(255, 52, 0, 0.5)',
                             line=dict(color='black',width=2)), # line color around bars
                text = df2021["Overall rank"]) # text on hover

# create trace2(Freedom to make life choices)
trace2 = go.Bar(
                x = df2021["Country name"],
                y = df2021["Freedom to make life choices"],
                name = "Freedom to make life choices",
                marker = dict(color = 'rgba(0, 99, 25, 0.7)',
                              line=dict(color='black',width=2)),
                text =df2021["Overall rank"]) # text on hover

# create trace3 (Perceptions of corruption)
trace3 = go.Bar(
                x = df2021["Country name"],
                y = df2021["Perceptions of corruption"],
                name = "Perceptions of corruption",
                marker = dict(color = 'rgba(106, 90, 205, 1)',
                              line=dict(color='black',width=2)),
                text =df2021["Overall rank"]) # text on hover

# We combine traces
data = [trace1, trace2, trace3]
"""
A different way of creating a layout.
barmode = bar mode of bars like grouped
"""
layout = go.Layout(barmode = "group")
fig = go.Figure(data = data, layout = layout)
iplot(fig)
source.a4e0fc95:
"""
We will create an example using typ 3.
We want to see the happiness rate of the regions
"""

# We put our singular regions on a list
regions =list(world_happiness_report_2021["Regional indicator"].unique()) 
# happiness rates of regions
regions_happiness_rate = []
"""
To find the happiness rate of the region;
We collect the happiness rate of the countries in that region.
and divide by the number of countries in that region.

example: 
i = western Europe
x = all countries in this region.
happiness_rate = sum of happiness rates / x
"""
for i in regions:
    x = world_happiness_report_2020[world_happiness_report_2020["Regional indicator"] == i]
    happiness_rate = sum(x["Ladder score"]) / len(x)
    regions_happiness_rate.append(happiness_rate) # add list

# figure
# We create a figure and do it for its operations.
fig = {
  "data": [
    {
      "values": regions_happiness_rate,
      "labels": regions, # region names on the side
      "domain": {"x": [0, .8]}, # chart size
      "name": "Happiness Rate",
      "hoverinfo":"label+percent+name", # text on hover
      "hole": .3, # the size of the hole in the middle
      "type": "pie" # chart type
    },],
  "layout": {
        "title":"Happiness Rates by Region", # chart title
        "annotations": [ # regulation of chart
            { "font": { "size": 13},
              "showarrow": True, # show arrow on
              "text": "Happiness Rate", # arrow text
                "x": 0.2, # x-axis
                "y": 0.9 # y-axis
            },
        ]
    }
}
iplot(fig)
source.5cefb14c:
"""
Can't we draw a pie chart using type1 ? Of course we can draw.
We can use whichever comes easy.

Let's look at the happiness rate of the years.

why head (145)?
As the number of countries changes by years.
to give a more accurate result.
"""
### we get years of happiness
sum_happiness_rate_2021 = sum(world_happiness_report_2021["Ladder score"].head(145))
sum_happiness_rate_2020 = sum(world_happiness_report_2020["Ladder score"].head(145))
sum_happiness_rate_2019 = sum(world_happiness_report_2019["Score"].head(145))
sum_happiness_rate_2018 = sum(world_happiness_report_2018["Score"].head(145))
sum_happiness_rate_2017 = sum(world_happiness_report_2017["Happiness.Score"].head(145))
sum_happiness_rate_2016 = sum(world_happiness_report_2016["Happiness Score"].head(145))
sum_happiness_rate_2015 = sum(world_happiness_report_2015["Happiness Score"].head(145))

#years
years = ["2021","2020","2019","2018","2017","2016","2015"]
#We put our rate on a list
years_happiness_rate = [sum_happiness_rate_2021,sum_happiness_rate_2020,sum_happiness_rate_2019,sum_happiness_rate_2018,
        sum_happiness_rate_2017,sum_happiness_rate_2016,sum_happiness_rate_2015]
# creat trace
trace =go.Pie(                   
    values=years_happiness_rate,
    labels=years, # years names on the side
    domain={"x":[0,.8]},
    marker = dict(line=dict(color='black',width=2.5)), # lines around the pie chart
    name= "Happiness Rate",
    insidetextorientation="radial", # articles according to the shape of the chart
    pull=[0.3, 0, 0, 0.2,0]) #  We indicate the places I want to separate from our pie chart.

#create data
data = [trace]
#create layout
layout = dict(title = 'Happiest Year')

fig = dict(data=data,layout=layout)
iplot(fig)
source.446fcc26:
"""
We will look at the happiness 
rates of the regions and the number of countries in those regions in a single graph.

y = happiness rate
x = region names
color = Healthy life expectancy
size = number of countries
"""
# regions
regions =list(world_happiness_report_2021["Regional indicator"].unique()) 
# happiness rates of regions
regions_happiness_rate = []
# Healthy life expectancy
healty_rate = []
# region_names
region_names = []
# number of countries
number_countries = [] 

"""
we have countries' happiness rate and healthy life expectancy.
We will calculate the regions using them.

i = region
x = all countries in that region
happiness_rate = happiness rate of the region.
healty = average healthy life expectancy of the region
region_ names = region names
number_countries = the number of countries in that region
"""
for i in regions:
    x = world_happiness_report_2021[world_happiness_report_2021["Regional indicator"] == i]
    happiness_rate = sum(x["Ladder score"]) / len(x)
    healty = sum(x["Healthy life expectancy"] / len(x))
    healty_rate.append(healty) # healty rate add
    regions_happiness_rate.append(happiness_rate) # add list
    region_names.append(i) # region names add
    number_countries.append(len(x))  # number of countries add

data = [
    {
        'y': regions_happiness_rate,
        'x': region_names,
        'mode': 'markers',
        'name': 'Happiness Rate',
        "hoverinfo":"x+y+name", # text on hover
        'marker': {
            'color': healty_rate,# health rate of the region
            'size': number_countries, # by the number of countries
            'showscale': True #scale on the side
        },
            
    }
]
iplot(data)
source.47068a87:
### healthy life expectancy rates over the past three years

# Since the data of 2021 is different from other years;
## we do a little normalization
### to be a more accurate graphic
world_happiness_report_2021["Healthy life expectancy"] =world_happiness_report_2021["Healthy life expectancy"] /max(world_happiness_report_2021["Healthy life expectancy"])

# create trace1(For the year 2021) 
trace1 = go.Histogram(
    x=world_happiness_report_2021["Healthy life expectancy"].head(30),# top 30 countries
    opacity=1, # opacity of the bars in the chart
    name = "2021",
    marker=dict(color='rgba(10, 99, 0, 1)')) 
# create trace1(For the year 2020) 
trace2 = go.Histogram(
    x=world_happiness_report_2020["Healthy life expectancy"].head(30),# top 30 countries
    opacity=1, # opacity of the bars in the chart
    name = "2020",
    marker=dict(color='rgba(10, 99, 0, 1)')) 
# create trace2(For the year 2019)
trace3 = go.Histogram(
    x=world_happiness_report_2019["Healthy life expectancy"].head(30), #top 30 countries
    opacity=0.8,
    name = "2019",
    marker=dict(color='rgba(255, 0, 20, 0.8)'))

# create trace3(For the year 2018)
trace4 = go.Histogram(
    x=world_happiness_report_2018["Healthy life expectancy"].head(30), #top 30 countries
    opacity=0.6,
    name = "2018",
    marker=dict(color='rgba(30, 0, 200, 0.6)'))

data = [trace1, trace2,trace3,trace4]

layout = go.Layout(barmode='overlay', # mode of histogram like overlay. Also you can change it with stack
                   title='Healthy life expectancy by years',
                   xaxis=dict(title='Healthy life expectancy'),
                   yaxis=dict( title='Count'),
)
fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
iplot(fig)

# our data
social_support = world_happiness_report_2021["Social support"]
generosity = world_happiness_report_2021["Generosity"]
freedom_of_choice = world_happiness_report_2021["Freedom to make life choices"]

# create trace
trace0 = go.Box(
    y=social_support, # the data we want to visualize
    name = 'Social Support', 
    boxpoints='all', # Show all points(you can false)
    jitter=0.3,
    pointpos=-1.5,
    marker = dict(
        color = 'rgba(0, 99, 0,0.8)', # we choose color ### I described rgba above
    )
)
# create trace1
trace1 = go.Box(
    y=generosity, # the data we want to visualize
    boxpoints='all', # Show all points(you can false)
    jitter=0.3,
    name = 'Generosity',
    notched=True,
    pointpos=-1.5,
    marker = dict(
        color = 'rgba(255, 25, 28,0.7)',
    ))

# create trace2
trace2 = go.Box(
    y=freedom_of_choice, # the data we want to visualize
    name = 'Fredom of Choice',
    boxpoints='all', # Show all points(you can false)
    jitter=0.3,
    pointpos=-1.5,
    marker = dict(
        color = 'rgba(111, 11, 85,0.7)',
    )
)
data = [trace0, trace1,trace2]
iplot(data)
source.13a00985:
# import figure factory
import plotly.figure_factory as ff

# prepare data
dataframe = world_happiness_report_2021
"""
Which columns will we look at the relationships between.
"""
data2021 = dataframe.loc[:,["Ladder score","Social support", "Healthy life expectancy"]]
# We determine our indexes
data2021["index"] = np.arange(1,len(data2021)+1)

# scatter matrix
fig = ff.create_scatterplotmatrix(data2021, diag='box', index='index',colormap='Portland',
                                  colormap_type='cat', title="Ladder score & Social support & Healthy life expectancy",
                                  height=700, width=700)
iplot(fig)
source.042b9a54:
# first line plot
# our chart will be big
trace1 = go.Scatter(
    x=world_happiness_report_2021["Overall rank"], # x-axis
    y=world_happiness_report_2021["Social support"], # y-axis
    name = "Social support",
    marker = dict(color = 'rgba(16, 112, 2, 1)'),
)
# second line plot
trace2 = go.Scatter(
    x=world_happiness_report_2021["Overall rank"],
    y=world_happiness_report_2021["Explained by: Social support"],
    xaxis='x2',# x-axis of the small chart
    yaxis='y2', # y-axis of the small chart
    name = "Explained by: Social support",
    marker = dict(color = 'rgba(123, 25, 13, 0.6)'),
)
# merge data
data = [trace1, trace2]
layout = go.Layout(
    # x-axis of the small chart
    xaxis2=dict(
        domain=[0.05, 0.5], # place in the chart
        anchor='y2', # x-axis bond y-axis       
    ),
    yaxis2=dict(
        domain=[0.1, 0.5], # place in the chart
        anchor='x2', # y-axis bond x-axis
    ),
    title = 'Social Support vs Explained by: Social support',# title chart

)

fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
iplot(fig)

)

)

        domain=[0, 0.45],
        anchor='x2'
    ),
    yaxis3=dict(
        domain=[0.55, 1]
    ),
    yaxis4=dict(
        domain=[0.55, 1],
        anchor='x4'
    ),
    title = 'Social support, Logged GDP per capita, Generosity and Healthy life expectancy VS world happiness rankings'
)
fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
iplot(fig)
source.80d02422:
# we import our library
import plotly.express as px

# We choose our top 50 countries
happy = world_happiness_report_2021.head(50)

# information to be given when mouse over the country
hover_data = world_happiness_report_2021[["Overall rank","Regional indicator","Ladder score","Logged GDP per capita","Social support","Generosity"]]

fig = px.choropleth(happy,
                    locations=happy["Country name"],
                    locationmode="country names",
                    projection="natural earth",
                    hover_data=hover_data,
                    hover_name=happy["Country name"],
                    color="Overall rank",
                    color_continuous_scale=px.colors.sequential.Rainbow,
                    scope="world")
fig.show()
source.8a91778f:
# data prepararion
country_name = world_happiness_report_2021["Country name"].head(50)
plt.subplots(figsize=(8,8))
wordcloud = WordCloud(
                          background_color='black',
                          width=512,
                          height=384
                         ).generate(" ".join(country_name))
plt.imshow(wordcloud)
plt.axis('off')
plt.savefig('graph.png')

plt.show()

Bar Plot

Is a bar chart.they have lengths and heights according to the values they represent.Bars can be vertical or horizontal.Helps to compare categories.one axis shows the categories compared.Shows values on the other axis.
Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:

  • x, y : data for the chart.(inputs)
  • mode : type of line on chart.(lines, markers, vs.)
  • name :the name of the line.
  • marker :lines have properties.(color, vs.)
  • text :text on hover.

--> The drawing of the graph is the same as above.(Style1)
source.a36da956:
Outlier Detection

**Outlier :** An outlier is a data point in a data set that is distant from all other observations. A data point that lies outside the overall distribution of the dataset. ** Q1 --> ** First quarter.
** Q3 --> ** Third quarter.

** IQR --> ** **Q3 - Q1** **(interquartile distance)**

** lower bound --> ** **Q1 – 1.5(IQR)**
**upper limit -->** **Q3 + 1.5(IQR)**

** outlier --> ** **Values outside the lower and upper limits**
source.16a76476:
Missing Value

* Find Missing Value * Fill Missing Value
source.83edb72f:
Introduction

This file contains the Happiness Score for 153 countries along with the factors used to explain the score.The Happiness Score is a national average of the responses to the main life evaluation question asked in the Gallup World Poll (GWP), which uses the Cantril Ladder.

First, we examined the data in detail.We detected missing data and outliers. Later, we made visualizations using the plotly library.We gave information about the graphics.We used different visualization techniques.

Content :

  • Load and Check Data
  • Variable Description
  • Univariate Variable Analysis
    • Categorical Variable
    • Numerical Variable
  • Basic Data Analysis
  • Outlier Detection
  • Missing Value
    • Find Missing Value
    • Fill Missing Value
  • Visualization with Plotly
    • Line Plot
    • Scatter Plot
    • Bar Plot
    • Pie Plot
    • Bubble Plot
    • Histogram Plot
    • Box Plot
    • Scatter Matrix Plots
    • Inset Plot
    • 3D Scatter Plot with Colorscaling
    • Multiple Subplots
    • Choropleth Map
  • BONUS
    • WordCloud

source.a1e1aeef:
Scatter Matrix Plots

it helps us to see covariance and relation between more than 2 features

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
  • index : name of the index column in data array
  • data : array of the data with column headers.
  • diag : (‘scatter’, ‘histogram’ and ‘box')
  • height : sets the height of the chart.
  • widht : sets the width of the chart.
  • colormap : a bunch of colors.
  • pointpos : relative position of points wrt box.

Country name, Regional indicator.

* Numerical Variable :

Scatter Plot

Scatter plot is a projection plot. Each point on the graph represents a value. It needs the x and y-axis values.Each data is represented as a dot point, whose location is given by x and y columns.

  • x, y : data for the chart.(inputs)
  • mode : type of line on chart.(lines, markers, vs.)
  • name :the name of the line.
  • marker :lines have properties.(color, vs.)
  • text :text on hover.

--> The drawing of the graph is the same as above.(Style1)
source.9597e6b9:
There are many ways to draw graphics. You can use it if you prefer. I'll use this method to have variation in my example below.

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
  • x, y : data for the chart.(inputs)
  • mode : type of line on chart.(lines, markers, vs.)
  • name :the name of the line.
  • marker :lines have properties.(color, vs.)
  • type :type of plot like bar plot
  • barmode :Grouping method of bars.
Graphic Creation Stages(style2) :

1 -> Creating Traces :(Trace1,Trace2,...)

trace1 = {
  • x : 'x'
  • y : 'y'
  • name : name of the plots
  • marker : marker is used with dictionary.
  • type : type of plot like bar plot
    }

    • 2 -> Data : the data we add traces

    data = [Trace1,Trace2]

    3 -> layout : outer part of the chart.

    layout = {
    'xaxis':{'title':'label of x axis'
    'barmode':'how to draw graph'
    'title':'chart title'
    }

    4 -> fig : it includes data and layout.

    fig = go.Figure(data = data, layout = layout)

    5 -> iplot() : Draws the generated chart.

    iplot(fig)
source.82f9d05d: Looking above we see that there is no missing data in our data. we do not have missing data, we do not need to do the filling process.If you can create a model for machine learning in the future. Data should not be missing data.For a more accurate result.
source.a021e47f:
Line Plot

Line plot in Plotly is much accessible and illustrious annexation to plotly which manage variety of types of data, and assemble easy-to-style statistic.

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
* **x, y :** data for the chart.(inputs) * **mode :** type of line on chart.(lines, markers, vs.) * **name :** the name of the line. * **marker :** lines have properties.(color, vs.) * **text :** text on hover
Graphic Creation Stages(style1) :

1 -> Creating Traces :(Trace1,Trace2,...)

trace1 = go.Scatter(the graphic we use)(
  • x : x-axis
  • y : y-axis
  • mode
  • name
  • marker
  • text )

    • 2 -> Data :

    data = [Trace1,Trace2]

    3 -> layout : outer part of the chart.

    layout = dict(title : chart title, xaxis = dict(title = label of x axis,ticklen = length of x axis ticks, zeroline = showing zero line or not),yaxis = dict(title: label of y axis))

    4 -> fig : it includes data and layout.

    fig = dict(data = data, layout = layout)

    5 -> iplot() : Draws the generated chart.

    iplot(fig)
source.93a66688:
Box Plot

Draw a box plot to show distributions with respect to categories.A box plot (or box-and-whisker plot) shows the distribution of quantitative data in a way that facilitates comparisons between variables or across levels of a categorical variable. we usually use it to detect outliers.

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
  • y : the data we want to visualize.(input)
  • name : the name of the line.
  • marker : lines have properties.(color, vs.)
  • notched : provides a notched shape.
  • boxpointns : It allows all points to be displayed on the side.
  • jitter : provides better separation between points.
  • pointpos : relative position of points wrt box.
**Outlier :** An outlier is a data point in a data set that is distant from all other observations. A data point that lies outside the overall distribution of the dataset. ** Q1 --> ** First quarter.
** Q3 --> ** Third quarter.

** IQR --> ** **Q3 - Q1** **(interquartile distance)**

** lower bound --> ** **Q1 – 1.5(IQR)**
**upper limit -->** **Q3 + 1.5(IQR)**

** outlier --> ** **Values outside the lower and upper limits**
source.a16c8ae0:
Histogram Plot

In statistics, a histogram is representation of the distribution of numerical data, where the data are binned and the count for each bin is represented. More generally, in plotly a histogram is an aggregated bar chart, with several possible aggregation functions (e.g. sum, average, count...).

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
  • x : data for the chart.(input)
  • opacity : opacity of the bars in the chart
  • name : the name of the line.
  • histnorm : type of normalization
  • marker : lines have properties.(color, vs.)
  • log_y : represent bars with log scale
  • barmode : showing us how to draw the histogram

source.fa167787:
Choropleth Map

we use our data to view maps..

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
  • locations : data to be given according to the selected mode(we give the locations).
  • locationmode : We tell you how to draw the map(‘ISO-3’, ‘USA-states’, or ‘country names’).
  • projection : How will the map projections be.There are many types.(example : 'kavrayskiy7', 'miller', 'robinson', 'eckert4', 'azimuthal equal area').
  • hover_data : information to be given when mouse over the country.
  • hover_name : We can call it the title of hover data.
  • color : Coloring the map..
  • scope : viewpoint on the map.
  • color_continuous_scale : We can call it the form of coloring..

source.5506e146:
Bubble Plot

A bubble chart is a scatter plot in which a third dimension of the data is shown through the size of markers.New dimensions are gained by giving the color and size properties.

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
  • x, y : data for the chart.(inputs)
  • mode : type of line on chart.(lines, markers, vs.)
  • name :the name of the line.
  • hoverinfo :the text that will appear when mouse is over the graphic
  • marker :lines have properties.(color, vs.)

source.91cc4e38:
Variable Description

  1. Country name : We show the names of the countries.
  2. Regional indicator : Shows which region the country is in.
  3. Ladder score : Ladder score of countries.
  4. Standard error of ladder score : Showing the error rate in the ladder score.
  5. upperwhisker : upper limit of score.
  6. lowerwhisker : lowe limti of score.
  7. Logged GDP per capita : is the total monetary or market value of all the finished goods and services produced within a country's borders in a specific time period.
  8. Social support : social support scores of countries.
  9. Healthy life expectancy : healthy life expectancy of countries.
  10. Freedom to make life choices : the freedom of people in that country to choose life.
  11. Generosity : Generosity rate of the country.
  12. Perceptions of corruption : corruption perceptions in the country..
  13. Ladder score in Dystopia : Ladder score in Dystopia of the coutry (Dystopia: alternatively cacotopia or simply anti-utopia) is a community or society that is undesirable or frightening) .
  14. Explained by: Log GDP per capita : Explained Log GDP per capita ratio.
  15. Explained by: Social support : Explained social support rate.
  16. Explained by: Healthy life expectancy : Explained Healthy life expectancy
  17. Explained by: Freedom to make life choices : Explained Freedom to make life choices
  18. Explained by: Generosity : Explained Generosity
  19. Explained by: Perceptions of corruption : Explained Perceptions of corruption.
  20. Dystopia + residual : Dystopia + residual total rate.
source.de4667de:
If we examine the chart above;

  • We see it divided into 10 regions
  • These regions : Western Europe, North America and ANZ, Middle East and North Africa, Latin America and Caribbean, Central and Eastern Europe, East Asia, Southeast Asia, Commonwealth of Independent States, Sub-Saharan Africa.
  • Region with the most countries : Sub-Saharan Africa
  • Region with the fewest countries : North America and ANZ

source.b309b5fc:
Pie Plot

It is a circular graphic which is divided into slices to illustrate numerical proportion. The point of a pie chart is to show the relationship of parts out of a whole.

Parameters: The description of some main parameters are given below:
  • values : sizes of pie slices.(inputs)
  • labels : label for each piece of cake.
  • name :slice name.
  • marker :lines have properties.(color, vs.)
  • type :chart type
  • domain :area of the graphic.
  • hoverinfo :the text that will appear when mouse is over the graphic
  • hole :hole in the middle of the chart.
Graphic Creation Stages(style3) :

-> we form a direct figure.this time we define them all within the figure(not separately)

--> fig = {
--> "data": [ {

  • "values":
  • "labels":
  • "domain":
  • "name":
  • "hoverinfo":
  • "hole":
  • "type":
    • },],
    --> "layout": {
  • "title":"chart title",
    }

    --> iplot(fig)
